docs.lead_paragraph: THE meaning of a number depends on who is No. 1. As an ex-No. 1, Lleyton Hewitt pulled off a rarity for him as he scurried around Arthur Ashe Stadium yesterday without offending a linesman with a slur, infuriating his opponent with an obscene gesture or irritating the crowd with his excessive ''C'mons.''

headline.main: On and Off the Court, Federer Is Truly No. 1

docs.snippet: The meaning behind the world's No. 1 in tennis is universally lost or gained in the number of yes men.

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal government decision to add folic acid to enriched grain products has reduced the occurrence of two devastating birth defects, but more needs to be done, according to reports published Tuesday. A review of births in 21 states from 1995, a year before the fortification was authorized, to 2002 found ''significant decreases in the prevalence of spina bifida and anencephaly,'' two neural tube defects, a study said. Spina bifida results in spine damage, and anencephaly results in an incomplete brain.

headline.main: Adding Folic Acid to Grain Reduces Birth Defects, Study Finds

docs.abstract: Study by Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and University of Alabama published in journal Pediatrics shows addition of folic acid to enriched grain products has reduced occurrence of spina bifida and anencephaly, devastating birth defects; researchers found racial disparity, with children born to black women less likely to be protected (M)
docs.snippet: A federal government decision to add folic acid to enriched grain products has reduced the occurrence of two devastating birth defects, but more needs to be done, according to reports.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION

docs.lead_paragraph: Hour after hour, Antonia Lopez Paz said, her supervisor at the Koch Foods poultry plant here told women on the deboning line that production demands were so great that they could not go to the bathroom. Sometimes she developed acute pain because she could not go, Ms. Lopez said. And one time when another woman asked for permission, ''the supervisor took off his hard hat and told her, 'You can go to the bathroom in this,''' said Ms. Lopez, a Mexican immigrant who moved to this town in East Tennessee three years ago, lured by the company's promise of year-round work.

headline.main: Union Organizers at Poultry Plants in South Find Newly Sympathetic Ears

docs.abstract: Thriving unionization drive is growing in poultry plants in South, partly stemming from complaint by worker Antonia Lopez Paz that she was not permitted to leave her work station to use bathroom; United Food and Commercial Workers are organizing employees at two Koch Foods plants in Morristown, Tenn; union is one that broke away from AFL-CIO with promise of devoting far more energy to recruiting workers; as part of push, insurgent unions says they will seek to build deep community support among local houses of worship, political leaders and immigrant groups; most workers in area are Mexican and while they might seem ripe for organizing, labor's efforts face daunting obstacles in companies fighting back; many immigrants ultimately shy away from efforts, fearing retaliation; other organizing efforts in Southern states noted; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Two organizing drives aimed at poultry workers are among the early battles in the effort to reinvigorate labor.

docs.lead_paragraph: When a drug test for the banned blood booster EPO was developed by French scientists in 2000, it was hailed as a revolution. For the first time, a potent performance-enhancing drug, which had been abused with impunity in sports like cycling and distance running for nearly a decade, could be detected. But last month, when the same scientists tested for and detected EPO, or erythropoietin, in Lance Armstrong's frozen urine sample from the 1999 Tour de France, the credibility of Armstrong and the test itself came into question. EPO boosts endurance by increasing the oxygen-carrying capacity of blood.

headline.main: Antidoping Agency Seeks Test for EPO That Is Definitive

docs.snippet: Scientists say that drug tests for the banned blood booster EPO - which Lance Armstrong is accused of having in his system in 1999 - have limitations.

docs.lead_paragraph: MONDAY The News -- The Air Force issues new religion guidelines to its commanders. No promoting of a particular faith, they say, or even ''the idea of religion or nonreligion,'' in official communications or at official functions. Behind the News -- Complaints from Air Force Academy cadets that evangelical Christian superiors were using their positions to promote their religion led to the development of the guidelines, which do allow for ''a brief sectarian prayer'' at special ceremonies. TUESDAY The News -- White House officials explain how they plan to encourage Iraqis to ratify the proposed constitution. Behind the News -- Endorse the document? Not exactly. But Stephen J. Hadley, the national security adviser, said the United States could ''help explain, in Iraq and to the international community, what is in the document,'' and could work with the United Nations to give technical help to the Iraqis in voter registration and setting up polls. But ''the president has made clear that this is an Iraqi process,'' Mr. Hadley said. WEDNESDAY The News -- Protesting the Food and Drug Administration's delay in approving sales of the so-called morning-after pill without a prescription, a top agency official resigns. Behind the News -- The official, Dr. Susan F. Wood, who was director of the office of women's health, said the pill, known as Plan B, was a way to prevent pregnancy and should not be party to ''abortion politics.'' Opponents of abortion view Plan B as tantamount to abortion. The agency approved it as a prescription contraceptive in 1999. THURSDAY The News -- Scientists report that they have decoded the chimpanzee genome and compared it with humans'. Behind the News -- Monkey see the human genome sequenced, monkey want its own. And it turns out that there are 40 million differences that have arisen since chimps and humans split from a common ancestor six million years ago, which makes it a little difficult to find the changes caused by natural selection. But the comparison did offer insight into the evolution of human sexual behavior, scientists said. FRIDAY The News -- President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia meets with relatives of the victims of the school siege a year ago in Beslan and promises an accounting. Behind the News -- As the anniversary of the siege, which killed 331 people, 186 of them children, approached, a group called the Beslan Mothers' Committee led protests and challenged the official version of events, accusing the government of covering up a botched rescue. Mr. Putin did not directly address the fury of the relatives over the government's handling of the siege.

headline.main: Far From the Gulf Coast | Aug. 28-Sept. 3

docs.lead_paragraph: The two radio hosts, Majda and Majid, a chattering woman-and-man team, said the subject for the next hour would be childbearing and motherhood, from the first flush of pregnancy to the tribulations of labor. So Majda opened the show with a poem, dedicating it to the ''mother of Baghdad'': ''You are my darling, you are the flower of my table, you are my drink.''

headline.main: On the Air, on Their Own: Iraqi Women Find a Forum

docs.snippet: Radio Al Mahaba, an Iraqi station devoted to women's issues, falls between National Public Radio and "The Oprah Winfrey Show."

docs.lead_paragraph: Lilah Hilliard Fisher and Jeffrey Roland Wise, actors in New York, are to be married today in Holderness, N.H. James Diamond, a Universal Life Church minister, will perform the ceremony at the Chocorua Island Chapel, of which the bride's father is a trustee. The bride and bridegroom met at Colgate University, from which they both graduated cum laude.

docs.lead_paragraph: Jan Moor-Jankowski, a scientist known for groundbreaking immunology work with chimpanzees and whose life was defined by many impassioned battles, from fighting Nazis in his native Poland to defending press freedoms to exposing animal abuse, died on Aug. 27 at his home in Manhattan. He was 81. The cause was a stroke, his wife, Deborah, said.

headline.main: Jan Moor-Jankowski, 81; Used Chimps, Kindly, in Science

docs.abstract: Jan Moor-Jankowski, scientist known for immunology work with chimpanzees, dies on Aug 27 at age 81; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Jan Moor-Jankowski was known for groundbreaking immunology work with chimpanzees and for his many impassioned battles.

docs.lead_paragraph: OUTSIDE, it was a picture of autumnal beauty: The cool wind whipped across the front yard, stirring the burnished yellow and orange leaves blanketing the ground. But I was indoors, deep in the basement of my mother-in-law's farmhouse in upstate New York, toiling alongside her housekeeper, imported from the city for the weekend. As I scraped old contact paper from a kitchen cabinet drawer, I knew that I would not look back on this day with fondness. What I did not know then was that the day would also mark the beginning of a long and ugly battle between my husband's family and mine -- a battle that would take place on and primarily be about the family vacation compound. As is the case with most family disputes, each person involved has his or her own take on what happened, on who was the villain and who was the victim. There are many ways to tell this saga. This is mine.
docs.snippet: How one family's country home became a battleground, pitting sibling against sibling, wife against mother-in-law.

docs.lead_paragraph: Penguins versus grizzly bears: the battle for the hearts, minds and dollars of American moviegoers waged by the emperor penguins of Antarctica against the grizzly bears of Alaska in two widely praised summer documentaries has something to tell us about our appetite for reality. Whether taken with milk and cookies or swallowed as a gulp of bitter medicine, reality is something many would like a lot more of than the infotainment juggernaut is willing to supply. Some of the most revealing portals to the world beyond the glutinous mass culture that Martin Amis dubbed ''the moronic inferno'' are to be found in independent films.

headline.main: A Reprieve for Reality In New Crop of Films

docs.snippet: "March of the Penguins," "Grizzly Man" and other summer movies may not solve the riddles of existence, but they offer glimpses into the real world.

multimedia.credit: Stephen Holden reviews two of the best documentaries of the summer, "March of the Pengiuns" and "Grizzly Man."
multimedia.caption: Movie Minutes: Summer's Best Documentaries
